raw_text:
Mobile picture power in your pocket
 
 How many times have you wanted to have a camera to hand to catch an unexpected event that would make headlines?
 
 With a modern mobile phone that has a camera built in, you no longer need to curse, you can capture the action as it happens. Already on-the-spot snappers are helping newspapers add immediacy to their breaking news stories headlines, where professional photographers only arrive in time for the aftermath. Celebrities might not welcome such a change because they may never be free of a new breed of mobile phone paparazzi making their lives a bit more difficult. Already one tabloid newspaper in LA is issuing photographers with camera phones to help them catch celebrities at play. It could be the start of a trend that only increases as higher resolution phone cameras become more widespread; as video phones catch on and millions of people start carrying the gadgets around.
 
 Only last week, the world media highlighted the killing of the Dutch film maker Theo van Gogh, notorious after making a controversial film about Islamic culture.
 
 One day later De Telegraaf, a daily Amsterdam newspaper, became news on its own when it published a picture taken with a mobile phone of Mr van Gogh's body moments after he was killed. "This picture was the story", said De Telegraaf's image editor, Peter Schoonen. Other accounts of such picture phone users witnessing news events, include:
 
 
  - A flight from Switzerland to the Dominican Republic which turned around after someone took a picture of a piece of metal falling from the plane as it took off from Zurich (reported by the Swiss daily Le Matin). 
  - Two crooks who robbed a bank in Denmark were snapped before they carried out the crime waiting for the doors of the building to be opened (reported by the Danish regional paper Aarhus Stiftstidende). 
  
 
 But this is not just about traditional media lending immediacy to their stories with content from ordinary people, it is also about first-hand journalism in the form of online diaries or weblogs.
 
 It has been called "open source news" or even "moblog journalism" and it has flourished in the recent US election campaign. "Not many people walk around with their cameras, but they always have their mobile phones with them. If something happens, suddenly all these mobiles sort of appear from nowhere, and start taking pictures," said digital artist Henry Reichhold. He himself uses mobile phone pictures to create huge panoramic images of events and places. "You see it in bars, you see it everywhere. It's a massive thing," Mr Reichhold told the BBC News website.
 
 With some picture agencies already paying for exclusive phone pictures, especially of celebrities, there are also fears about the possible downside of this phenomenon.
 
 It could become a nuisance for public figures as higher resolution picture phones hit the market, with five megapixel models already being launched in Asia. Already on US photojournal site, Buzznet, there is a public album full of snaps of celebrities, many of which were taken with camera phones. Tabloid newspapers in the UK and many monthly magazines invite readers to send in images of famous people they have seen and snapped. But there are other positive uses of picture mobile phones that may balance these uses. For instance, in Alabama, in the US, camera phones will be used to take snaps at crime scenes involving children, and help the authorities to arrest and prosecute paedophiles. And in China's capital Beijing, courts have adopted mobile phone photos as formal evidence. For Henry Reichhold, this is progress: "That's the whole thing about the immediacy of the thing. I can see that happening a lot more."
llama3.2:1b:
Here is a concise summary of the text:

Mobile phones with built-in cameras allow people to capture events as they happen, increasing media coverage and reducing reliance on professional photographers.
The trend includes tabloid newspapers issuing camera phones to paparazzi, video phones catching on, and online diaries or weblogs being used for first-hand journalism.

Traditional media faces challenges from mobile phone users who can take pictures of news events, but fears include potential downsides such as nuisance to public figures and unauthorized use of high-resolution images.
llama3.2:3b: A modern mobile phone with a camera built-in allows people to capture unexpected events firsthand, making headlines for news stories and challenging traditional professional photographers.

This phenomenon, known as "open source news" or "moblog journalism," has led to the publication of photos taken by ordinary people at breaking news events, such as the murder of Dutch film maker Theo van Gogh.
As higher resolution phone cameras become more widespread, concerns arise about the potential nuisance for public figures and the need for regulation.
However, there are also positive uses of picture mobile phones, such as using them to aid in crime scene investigations and formal evidence in court cases.
gemma2:2b: Mobile phones with cameras are increasingly capturing news events, from breaking stories to crime scenes.
This phenomenon has led to new forms of journalism and increased access to news.

While concerns exist about privacy and potential misuse by paparazzi, mobile phone photography also has valuable applications like crime scene documentation and legal evidence, highlighting the power and potential of this technology in various contexts.
qwen2.5:0.5b: Mobile cameras are becoming increasingly popular for capturing action events without needing a camera body or remote control.
Celebrities and tabloids are already using them to capture breaking news stories, but some fear they could become too convenient and interfere with normal public life.

More advanced phones equipped with higher megapixel cameras will likely make the technology more mainstream, while others may be used for photojournalism, crime scene photography, or formal evidence in courts.
qwen2.5:1.5b:
Summary:
Mobile phones offer immediate capture capabilities for photojournalism and news coverage, influencing traditional media and paving the way for online journalism through picture apps like mobile phones, with concerns over privacy and potential legal issues.
qwen2.5:3b: Mobile phones with built-in cameras offer instant news coverage by capturing events in real-time.
This has already led to newspapers and tabloids using photos taken by regular people, including celebrities who may now face paparazzi attention.
Such photojournalism is especially prominent during breaking news stories like the killing of Dutch filmmaker Theo van Gogh.
High-resolution camera phones are also being used for open-source journalism, such as blogs and weblogs featuring first-hand accounts of events.
However, there are concerns about privacy issues involving public figures and increased resolution pictures, as well as potential misuse by some media outlets.
Despite these negatives, mobile phone photos continue to be accepted in official settings like crime scenes and court proceedings.

And in China's capital Beijing, courts have adopted mobile phone photos as formal evidence.
13) For Henry Reichhold, this is progress: "That's the whole thing about the immediacy of the thing.
I can see that happening a lot more."
smollm:1.7b: The text above summarizes the main ideas and key points from the given text.
The summary should be concise and to the point, preserving the original meaning and tone of the text while omitting unnecessary information.
The summary should also include any relevant details or examples that support the main idea.
deepseek-r1:1.5b: Mobile phone cameras have transformed media capture today, enabling immediate coverage of events like Theo van Gogh's death in the Netherlands.
Traditional media often relies on ordinary people' diaries or weblogs for first-hand journalism, while mobile photos offer immediacy and authenticity.
High-resolution phones and online diaries have flourished, spreading the narrative further than ever before.
tinyllama:1.1b: The growing trend of picture mobile phone use has already led to news reports featuring photojournalists who snap celebrities as they are being interviewed, and captured by their own devices during events such as protests or natural disasters.
This phenomenon has sparked a debate about the potential downside of this technology, with some fearing that it could lead to a new breed of celebrity paparazzi.

Despite these concerns, mobile phone cameras have already become an essential tool in news reporting and publishing, with tabloid newspapers in LA issuing photographers with camera phones as part of their coverage.
In addition, there are positive uses for the technology in investigative journalism and child crime cases, where camera phones may be used to take snapshots at crime scenes involving children.
This trend is set to continue with the emergence of camera phone evidence in criminal proceedings, and is part of a broader shift towards more immediate and accessible news coverage.
tinydolphin:1.1b: The article discusses the growing trend of picture mobile phones as an alternative to traditional photojournalism.

These devices allow people to capture moments in time with minimal effort or require little space, making them ideal for capturing events and incidents that would be difficult or impractical to photograph using traditional techniques.
With the advent of high-resolution camera phones, picture mobile phones are more powerful than ever before, allowing users to capture candid moments that might otherwise remain unnoticed.
This can lead to increased visibility and immediacy for these events, encouraging people to share their experiences and share in the news process.

However, there are also concerns about potential downsides, such as the possibility of stalkerish behavior from picture users or the risk of privacy invasion if they snap celebrities, who may not want their image taken.
phi:2.7b: A news article reports on how mobile phones with cameras have become increasingly popular for capturing breaking news events and moments, including photojournalism, eyewitness accounts, and public albums inviting readers to send in celebrity snapshots.
However, there are also concerns about the potential nuisance for public figures as higher-resolution camera phones become more widespread.

This is already happening with news events, and even celebrity events.
One day later, De Telegraaf, a daily Amsterdam newspaper, became news on its own when it published a picture taken with a mobile phone of Mr van Gogh's body moments after he was killed.

In addition, two crooks who robbed a bank in Denmark were snapped before they carried out the crime waiting for the doors of the building to be opened, and it was called "open source news" or even "moblog journalism".

This is progress because mobile phone cameras will be used to take snaps at crime scenes involving children, and help the authorities to arrest and prosecute paedophiles.
In China's capital Beijing, courts have adopted mobile phone photos as formal evidence.
For Henry Reichhold, this is progress: "That's the whole thing about the immediacy of the thing.
I can see that happening a lot more."
hermes3:3b: Mobile camera in phones for on-the-spot photos & breaking news captures.
Increased use may lead to higher res models, celeb paparazzi issues, but also potential benefits like child abuse prosecutions.
stablelm-zephyr:3b: Mobile phones with built-in cameras are becoming an important source of breaking news and first-hand journalism, also known as "moblog journalism."
People are using their mobile devices to capture photos of events, which then get published by traditional media or used in online diaries.
This trend is led by the wider availability of high-resolution picture phones and increasing numbers of people carrying them around.
However, there are concerns about possible downsides, such as mobile phone paparazzi making celebrities' lives difficult and potential nuisance to public figures.
Some positive uses include using camera phones at crime scenes in the US or adopting mobile phone photos as formal evidence in China's capital Beijing.
chatgpt-4o-latest: Mobile phones with built-in cameras are transforming news reporting by allowing ordinary people to capture breaking events instantly, often before professional photographers arrive.
This has led to a rise in "moblog journalism" and "open source news," where user-generated content enhances traditional media and online platforms.
Examples include a mobile photo of Dutch filmmaker Theo van Gogh’s murder and images that helped prevent a plane disaster and identify bank robbers.
While this trend benefits journalism, it also raises concerns about privacy, especially for celebrities, as high-resolution camera phones become more common.
Some media outlets even pay for exclusive mobile photos.
However, mobile photography also has positive applications, such as aiding law enforcement in crime investigations and serving as legal evidence in courts.
The immediacy and accessibility of mobile photography are expected to grow further.
stablelm2:1.6b: Mobile phones with cameras are changing news and reporting methods by allowing people to capture unexpected events instantly, contributing to breaking news stories.
This trend may increase as higher resolution phone cameras become more widespread and video phones catch on.
Examples of picture phone users witnessing news events include a Swiss-Danish bank robbery incident and the US election campaign.
Open-source news or moblog journalism is gaining popularity through first-hand journalism in the form of online diaries or weblogs.
Some photo agencies are paying for exclusive phone pictures, particularly of celebrities.
However, concerns about possible downsides to this phenomenon exist.
Despite these potential downsides, picture phones offer numerous positive uses that may balance their applications.
For instance, they can be used to take snapshots at crime scenes involving children and help law enforcement arrest and prosecute paedophiles in Alabama, USA.
In China's capital, Beijing, courts have adopted mobile phone photos as formal evidence.
granite3.1-dense:2b: Mobile phones equipped with cameras empower users to capture and report events in real-time, transforming the role of traditional photojournalists and expanding the reach of online first-hand journalism.
This development has already been observed in various news outlets, including De Telegraaf's publication of Theo van Gogh's image after his murder.
Mobile phone users have documented significant events worldwide, such as a plane incident from Switzerland and bank robberies in Denmark.
These snaps, often referred to as "open source news" or "moblog journalism," are increasingly valued by picture agencies for their immediacy and accessibility.
However, the widespread availability of high-resolution camera phones raises concerns about potential nuisances for public figures, particularly celebrities, who may face constant surveillance.
Despite these concerns, mobile phone photography also holds positive applications, like crime scene documentation in Alabama and court evidence in Beijing.
The trend is expected to grow as more advanced camera phones become accessible, potentially revolutionizing the way news is gathered and reported.
